talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Does the regulation Impact Statement for the Goods and Services Tax legislation claim that the number of Australian businesses that will be required to seek an Australian Business Number (ABN) is 1.4 million, rising to 1.6 million in 2001-02; if so, is this still the case.

(2) Is he aware that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts stated that up to 2.5 million Australian businesses will have an ABN by July 2000.
(3) What is the reason for the apparent discrepancy in the estimated number of businesses which will be registered for an ABN.
(4) What is the aggregate compliance cost impact of the extra registrations.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's amended question:

answer.para: (1) The Regulation Impact Statement for the Goods and Services Tax (GST) legislation refers to the number of GST registrations that are expected. It states at Part C.1:
"It is estimated that in the first year of operation there will be 1,400,000 GST registrations. The numbers are expected to grow by about 200,000 in the following year."
and at Part D.2 that:
"It is estimated that there will be 1.6 million registrations in 2001-02."
These estimates refer to GST registrations only, which is a subset of the much larger number of entities that are expected to apply for an Australian Business Number (ABN).

The figure for the number of GST registrations estimated for the first year of operation has been revised to 1,500,000 registrations and the number is expected to grow by about 300,000 in the following year.
(2) Such as statement would be in accordance with the most current Australian Taxation Office estimates for the number of expected ABN registrations based on the most recent information available.
(3) The reason for the apparent discrepancy in the estimated number of businesses which will be registered for an ABN is that not all entities that apply for an ABN will register for GST.

(4) For those registrants who choose to register for the purpose of enhancing their ability to deal in the future with the whole of government by using an ABN there will actually be compliance cost benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Will he provide a table showing the change that has occurred in the proportions of the various immigration categories since 1987.
(2) Has there been a significant reduction in the Extended Family Reunion and Parent categories relative to Independent categories.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to the social consequences of a significant change in the balance between the categories; if so, what research has his Department carried out on this issue.
(4) Will he act to re-balance the immigration program by providing a fair share for the family reunion categories; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) See table below.

(2) By "extended family reunion" categories, it is assumed to mean all family categories except Spouses/Fiances, Dependent Children and Parents but including the previous Concessional Family category and the Skilled-Australian Linked category.

On that basis, there has been a decline in the "extended family reunion" and Parents categories, relative to the Independent category over the period 1987-88 to 1998-99. This decline occurred substantially between 1987-88 and 1991-92. The relativity between these categories then fluctuated around a slightly higher figure for the rest of the period. The exception was 1995-96 when the proportion of Parents in the program jumped while the proportion of Independents slumped.

What the table in response to part (1) of this question also shows is that, in the period 1992-93 to 1995-96, the family reunion component of the program became out of balance with the Independent category and the Skill Stream more generally.

(3) The Government is committed to an immigration program that is in the national interest and one that has broad community support. Under the previous government, the Family Stream was allowed to dominate the Migration Program in a way that compromised the Program's contribution to the Australian economy and eroded community confidence in the Program. Against this background, the Government acted quickly to re-balance the Program through increasing the emphasis on skilled migration. The improved focus on skills helps to ensure that migrants contribute to, and share in, Australia's growth and that immigration is serving, in a balanced way, the goals of immigration policy in relation to Australia's economic, social, humanitarian and environmental interests.

The Department has undertaken an extensive research project in the form of the Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants to Australia (LSIA), which is the most comprehensive survey of immigrants ever to be undertaken in Australia. It is designed to collect and disseminate information about over 5000 migrants and accompanying family members who arrived in Australia between September 1993 and August 1995. Data collected reflects migrants' experiences of settlement in Australia over a period of time, from their pre-migration arrangements through until three years after their arrival. In broad terms, the aim of the survey is to provide Commonwealth and other agencies with reliable data with which to monitor and improve immigration and settlement policies, programs and services.

The sample for the survey was designed to enable comparison of immigration and settlement experiences by major migrant eligibility category (which were at time of survey design: preferential family; concessional family; business skills and employer nomination; independent and humanitarian) and also by about 50 regions or countries of birth.
The questionnaire covers a wide range of topics and includes questions on:
. demographic characteristics . health
. perceptions of Australia . general and social support
. views on immigration . financial support
. citizenship . sponsorship activity
. English proficiency/learning . household budget
. qualifications assessment . overseas assets/transfers
. study and training . changes of residence
. labour force status . return migration.
. dwelling type
Basic demographic information is collected on all members of the household, regardless of whether they were immigrants.

A second Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants to Australia (LSIA) is under development, with information to be collected from around 3 000 primary applicants, arriving between September 1999 and August 2000. Comparisons with data from the first LSIA will allow other effects of policy changes introduced by this Government to be evaluated. The second LSIA is also designed to enable comparisons between migrant eligibility categories (visa types) at a finer level of detail than the first LSIA.

A recently released report prepared by ACIL Consulting, titled Impact of Migrants on the Commonwealth Budget, indicates that from their first year in Australia the overall impact on the Commonwealth Budget of people arriving under the Migration Program is positive and this positive impact increases substantially over time. This good outcome is a result of the large positive impact of the Business and Independent skilled categories from their first year after arrival. This reinforces the Government's decision to focus on skilled migration.
Chris Murphy of Econtech has estimated that the increased emphasis on skill will provide a $134 per capita improvement in living standards by 2007-08.

The Department is also funding CSIRO to undertake work on the Australian Stocks and Flows Framework model, which was constructed by the CSIRO as part of its efforts to develop a system of national accounts in physical terms, to complement the national economic accounts. The CSIRO claims that the ASFF provides the first integrated overview of the long-term physical consequences of our economic and social choices.

A series of workshops are being held in 1999 in which a range of experts will examine and validate the assumptions of the model. Following this, the model will be used to examine the effect of three different population levels on a set of physical, social and demographic indicators to the year 2051. These results will be made publicly available.

(4) The question is based on a false premise that the Migration Program does not provide a fair share for family reunion. The actions this Government has taken have been designed to bring back into balance a program which was dominated by family reunion during the last four years of the previous Government. The current Family Stream provides places for around 47% of the Migration (non-Humanitarian) Program.
Please note that figures have been rounded and total may not be the exact sum of the components. They exclude humanitarian entry data.

The program outcomes and components comprise the number of visas granted and those granted permanent resident status in Australia after arrival. Figures include Grant of Resident Status (GORS) and, from 1989-90, also include people granted resident status under Permanent Entry Permit After Entry (PEPAE). There is no eligibility for PEPAE under the Concessional Family and Independent categories.
(*) Estimated GORS/PEPAE approvals. These figures were not attributed to sub-components until 1989-90.

(a) From 1997-98, Concessional Family was known as Skilled-Australian Linked Category and was shifted from the Family Stream to the Skill Stream on 1 July 1997 following major changes to the eligibility criteria focusing more on employability factors
(b) Includes Employer Nomination Scheme (ENS), Labour Agreements and Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme (RSMS).
(c) Business Migration Program changed to Business Skills during 1991-92.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1999:

question.para: (1) How many of the Kosovar refugees remaining in Australia fled Eastern Serbia into Kosovo.
(2) Will those refugees be forced to return to Kosovo.
(3) If not, will they be forced to return to Serbia; if so, have inquiries been made about where those persons will live once returned.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I do not have any information about how many of the Kosovar evacuees remaining in Australia fled Eastern Serbia into Kosovo. The Kosovar evacuees who came to Australia were selected from camps in Macedonia. I am aware that some of the Kosovars who came here said, after they had been in Australia for some time, that they were from Serbia. I do not know how these people who said they were from Serbia came to be in the Former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. The majority of the Kosovars who said they were from Serbia have now returned to Kosovo.
(2) All the evacuees agreed to return to Kosovo when it was secure to do so. At this stage all the Kosovar evacuees who have returned to Kosovo have done so voluntarily.
(3) I do not intend to return any of the Kosovar evacuees to Serbian controlled territory.
(4) The Premiers of Victoria and Tasmania have both written to me asking for the Kosovar evacuees to be allowed to remain in Australia.

(5) Yes, the legislation passed by the Australian Parliament that provided for a temporary stay for the Kosovar evacuees put a legislative bar on applications for any other type of visas while the Kosovars remained in Australia. I have invited all remaining Kosovars to set out any reasons they have for wanting to stay in Australia longer so that individual circumstances can be properly considered on their merits. talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) There are already a number of overseas aid funds approved under the income tax laws providing relief in East Timor.
Where a business makes a donation of property to one of the approved overseas aid funds a deduction will be allowable. The amount of the deduction will depend on the type of property donated.

Where the business donates an item of trading stock of the business which is disposed outside the ordinary course of the business, a deduction will generally be allowable for the market value of the property on the day the gift is made.

Where the property donated is not trading stock of a business, a deduction will generally be allowable for the lesser of the market value of the property on the day the gift is made or the amount paid for the property.
(2) The `purchase within 12 months condition', will not be waived.

However, under the new philanthropy measures announced by the Prime Minister on 26 March 1999 and contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8), from 1 July 1999 any property valued by the Commissioner of Taxation at more than $5,000 will not need to satisfy the 12 month rule.
In addition, the 12 month rule does not generally apply to donations of trading stock disposed of outside the ordinary course of business.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Have any aid organisations been deemed as approved organisations under the developing country gift deduction arrangements for relief work in East Timor; if so, what are the contact details for those approved organisations.

(2) Will the Government provide relief funding for the rebuilding of infrastructure in East Timor; if so, will the funding be directed to existing aid organisations or will the Government provide relief direct to the population of East Timor.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Overseas Aid Gift Deduction Scheme (OAGDS), the Government approves organisations which meet criteria that establish the relief and development credentials of the organisation. The Treasurer then approves specific funds established for relief of persons in declared developing countries. The Government does not monitor where the organisations that have tax-deductibility spend their donations. Tax-deductible funds have been approved that allow NGOs to work in a number of developing countries using donated monies. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) maintains a list of NGOs with tax-deductibility that are working in Timor on its website (www.acfoa.asn.au). On its website ACFOA notes that tax deductible cash donations are being accepted by many NGOs including the following, all of which are Government accredited:

entry.para: National Council of Churches in Australia

answer.para: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has included East Timor in the List of Declared Developing Countries and Territories for the purposes of the OAGDS.

(2) Australia has provided $14 million for humanitarian relief to East Timor since August 1999. This early assistance in providing emergency relief goods and logistical support has been critical to a quick and effective response to the humanitarian needs of the East Timorese.

As international agencies specialising in relief and development work are able to carry out de tailed assessments of humanitarian and development needs, the Government will consider making further assistance available. This is likely to include funding for the rebuilding of infrastructure in East Timor and support to a range of areas such as health, education, governance, agriculture and rural development.

Australia's future humanitarian support for East Timor is likely to be through a combination of international trust funds, direct bilateral assistance, funding of UN agencies, local, Australian and international NGOs, as well as various East Timorese church and community groups.
